int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"a highly structured tutoring program that fo-
cused on the development of very early reading skills,
including phonemic awareness and phonics. The pro-
gram was speciﬁcally designed to be easy enough to
implement that very little training would be required.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"The lessons, provided to the tutors during the ini-
tial training phase, included several levels that became
progressively more challenging. The ﬁrst level involved
an interactive game, “Stop and Go” (described below),
which introduced phonemic awareness and letter-sound
correspondence. Once the student could identify and
pronounce a small number of letter sounds, the stu-
dents moved to the next level, during which they played
a more challenging version of the game and completed
word-study activities (described below). As students
progressed, theymoved to more challengingword-study
activities and the gamewas replaced with the reading of
leveled books. Tutors were given guidelines to follow
to determine when a student should proceed to more
difﬁcult lessons.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Tutors participated in three one-hour train-
ing sessions andreceivedoccasional on-site assistance.[¬e]"', 'Page 2:
[¬s]"could college students with only minimal training and
assistance fully implement a highly structured tutoring
program designed to increase the early reading devel-
opment of at-risk ﬁrst graders?[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"During each year of the project, three formal one-hour
group training sessions were held. Approximately one-
half of the tutors participated regularly in the training
sessions. In addition to the group training sessions, all
tutors were given additional assistance onsite. Project
staff were always available the ﬁrst time a tutor con-
ducted a tutoring session and generally modeled at least
one session for each tutor. More individual training was
provided for tutors who did not participate in training
sessions. Project staff also assisted tutors onsite peri-
odically over the course of the research project. The
amount ofassistance varied from tutor to tutor depend-
ing on the needs of the tutors and the schedules of the
tutors and project staff. Project staffworked with tutors
and teachers to develop supervision schedules. Project
staffchecked records and contacted tutors at least once
every two to threeweeks."
"In Year 1, tutors participated in group training ses-
sions in October, November, and January for a total
of three hours of training. The ﬁrst session focused
on basic lesson procedures, pacing, feedback, student
motivation, handling behavior problems, school proto-
col, and various logistics. During the second session, in
November, tutors learned to implement a phonemic
awareness activity to use with their students who were
not successful in early lessons and they learned the pro-
cedures for book-reading activities for students who
were progressing quickly. Other issues discussed were
record keeping, motivation, pacing, and scheduling. In
the ﬁnal group training session in January, the session
focused on three main topics: (1) questions and details,
such as positive reinforcement and absences; (2) review
of book-reading activities; and (3) monitoring student
progress and pacing.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"the college stu-
dents only received three hours of training and they
used scripted lessons designed to teach very early read-
ing skills to ﬁrst graders highly at risk for reading
failure.[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"All tutors were college students majoring in education
who were unpaid volunteers or America Reads mem-
bers who were paid a monthly stipend. None of the
students had completed courses in reading methods."
"America Reads members were expected to serve[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"900 hours over the course of one calendar year and
were given an educational stipend if they completed
the entire 900 hours. The majority of the tutoring was
conducted by America Reads members. Typically, vol-
unteers were assigned to tutor approximately two hours
per week, whereas America Reads members tutored be-
tween 10–15 hours per week. In Year 1, 12 volunteers
and ﬁve America Reads members participated."
"each America Reads tutor was assigned
one or two schools in which they spent the majority of
their tutoring time, conducting sessions in each ofthose
schools at least two times each week. The schedules of
each tutor varied considerably and changed in January
of each year when college class schedules changed.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"The number of dif- ferent students tutored by any one tutor varied, but all students were tutored individually. The vast majority of the students in the study were tutored by two different tutors."
"Tutors were given guidelines to follow
to determine when a student should proceed to more
difﬁcult lessons. During their regular observations,
research assistants assessed lesson difﬁculty and helped
the tutors make adjustments to the lesson pace when
necessary.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"During both years of the study, tutoring sessions were
scheduled for three to four times per week; however,"
"on average, they were conducted two to three times per
week (due to tutor and/or student absences).[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"To measure the degree to which the tutoring pro-
cedures were implemented, we developed an obser-
vation checklist incorporating all behaviors that were
supposed to occur during each tutoring session (see
Appendix). All items were scored as occurring, not oc-
curring, or not applicable (i.e., student made no errors;
therefore, no feedback was required). Implementation
ﬁdelity was calculated by determining the percentage of
behaviors that occurred, not including those items that
were not applicable."
"In Year 1, ﬁve America Reads members conducted
the majority of the tutoring, typically tutoring 10–
15 hours each week. Project staff formally observed
each ofthem during four tutoring sessions across the in-
tervention period and included observations with vary-
ing students. The scores ofthese ﬁve tutors ranged from
75.38–88.00 percent, with a total mean implementation
of 82.97 percent (SD = 5.92)."
"Due to logistical problems,
including tutor absences, we were unable to observe
three of the 12 volunteers. The remaining nine vol-
unteers were observed two times each. The degree of
implementation across these nine tutors was slightly
higher than the America Reads members, with a mean
of 89.21 percent (SD = 4.38) and scores ranging from
80.59–95.00 percent. The overall mean for all tutors
during the ﬁrst year was 86.98 percent (SD = 5.67)."
"We collected interobserver reliability on 11 ofthe 38
(29 percent) ﬁdelity observations during Year 1[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"reliability was strong, with 90 percent overall relia-
bility in Year 1[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"During each year of the project, three formal one-hour
group training sessions were held. Approximately one-
half of the tutors participated regularly in the training
sessions. In addition to the group training sessions, all
tutors were given additional assistance onsite. Project
staff were always available the ﬁrst time a tutor con-
ducted a tutoring session and generally modeled at least
one session for each tutor. More individual training was
provided for tutors who did not participate in training
sessions. Project staff also assisted tutors onsite peri-
odically over the course of the research project."
"In Year 1, tutors participated in group training ses-
sions in October, November, and January for a total
of three hours of training. The ﬁrst session focused
on basic lesson procedures, pacing, feedback, student
motivation, handling behavior problems, school proto-
col, and various logistics. During the second session, in
November, tutors learned to implement a phonemic
awareness activity to use with their students who were
not successful in early lessons and they learned the pro-
cedures for book-reading activities for students who
were progressing quickly. Other issues discussed were
record keeping, motivation, pacing, and scheduling. In
the ﬁnal group training session in January, the session
focused on three main topics: (1) questions and details,
such as positive reinforcement and absences; (2) review
of book-reading activities; and (3) monitoring student
progress and pacing."
"In Year 2, tutors participated in group training ses-
sions in September, October, and January. The sessions
were very similar to Year 1 training sessions, except
that we were able to streamline training based on our
experiences in Year 1. We were better able to predict
the skills that would be required of the tutors in their
early tutoring; therefore, we provided the tutors with
less information in each session, focusing on informa-
tion that we had found to be critical during the ﬁrst year.
For example, we focused on the correct pronunciation
of a smaller number of sounds in the ﬁrst training ses-
sion than we had in Year 1. We also focused more on
logistical concerns, such as scheduling, absences, and
paperwork.[¬e]"']

cedures were implemented, we developed an obser-

int_training_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"Teachers’ intensive training constitutes an important component in early interventions (Lauren &
Allen, 1999). During the school year, the four university students underwent training at Tel Aviv
University for their role as student-mediators. Each pair of student-mediators working on the same
program (either joint reading or joint writing) attended separate 1-h weekly meetings with the co-
ordinator. In these meetings, the student-mediators shared their experiences from the previous week
and learned the contents and goals of the coming week’s sessions, including the connections to the
earlier sessions."
"During the weekly supervision meetings, the students received printed one-page
guidelines for each of the upcoming week’s sessions, as well as the necessary materials (games, books,
stickers, etc.). Students also talked about the materials they would have to prepare for these sessions
(printing certain words, clipping words from newspapers, bringing costumes for a show, etc.) and
discussed possible difﬁculties[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"Teachers’ intensive training constitutes an important component in early interventions (Lauren &
Allen, 1999). During the school year, the four university students underwent training at Tel Aviv
University for their role as student-mediators. Each pair of student-mediators working on the same
program (either joint reading or joint writing) attended separate 1-h weekly meetings with the co-
ordinator. In these meetings, the student-mediators shared their experiences from the previous week
and learned the contents and goals of the coming week’s sessions, including the connections to the
earlier sessions."
"During the weekly supervision meetings, the students received printed one-page
guidelines for each of the upcoming week’s sessions, as well as the necessary materials (games, books,
stickers, etc.). Students also talked about the materials they would have to prepare for these sessions
(printing certain words, clipping words from newspapers, bringing costumes for a show, etc.) and
discussed possible difﬁculties. Research has shown students to be useful in promoting kindergartners’
literacy (Ukrainetz et al., 2000). The student-mediators entered the preschools speciﬁcally for the
purpose of mediating this intervention and were available to meet consistently with each child twice
weekly.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"The interventions’ coordinator visited each preschool once every 2 weeks, for about an hour, in
order to provide teachers and student-mediators with frequent opportunities to discuss their negative
and positive reactions to the early literacy practices (see Baker & Smith, 1999). The teachers and the
student-mediators also attended monthly meetings in their preschools with the head coordinator. In
these meetings, the teachers, students, and the coordinators had an opportunity to discuss speciﬁc is-
sues that arose during that month. During the meetings, the teachers reported their impressions about
the children’s progress, and the coordinators described in general the next aims for the coming month.
These meetings aimed to enhance teachers’ awareness about the program’s ongoing goals and to en-
courage teachers to integrate literacy-related experiences into their activities with their entire preschool
class.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 180:
[¬s]"Preskill Training. Subjects in the Preskill Training condition received 30 minutes of instruc\xad tion for nine days on preskills related to decoding regular, multisyllabic words."
"The first preskill taught each day was auditory
blending of word parts. In this format, the instructor
orally presented multisyllabic words in a segmented[¬e]"', 'Page 182:
[¬s]"fashion (e.g., in-con-sis-tent), pausing two seconds
between each word part, and asked students to pronounce
the whole word."
"Initially, the words included
three or four word parts and were famililar words (e.g.,
sec-re-tar-y; pas-sen-ger). In later lessons, the
words increased in length and included lower fre\xad
quency multisyllabic words"
"The second preskill involved saving isolated vowel
sounds for vowel combinations."
"The instructor modeled
the phoneme and asked the students to repeat the sound.
These procedures were followed for each of the new
vowel combinations.[¬e]"', 'Page 183:
[¬s]"When an error occurred either
on unison or individual responses, the teacher modeled
the sound and tested the student (s) on the sound alter\xad
nating with other examples until the student(s) was
firm."
"In the following format, vowel conversions, stu\xad
dents were asked to say the letter name (glided
phoneme) or letter sound (unglided phoneme) for single
letter graphemes. Initially the teacher modeled the
sound and letter name and asked the students to repeat
the sound or letter name. This introduction was
followed by discrimination practice in which the sound
or letter name was required.[¬e]"', 'Page 184:
[¬s]"As a preskill to reading multisyllabic words, stu\xad
dents were taught that each part of a longer word has a
vowel sound and to locate the vowel graphemes repre\xad
senting these sounds. In this format, circling vowel
graphemes in words, students were asked to circle vowel
graphemes in multisyllabic words and to say the phoneme
for the grapheme."
"On the first items, the teacher
demonstrated the skill by circling the vowel graphemes
in words. After circling the graphemes, the teacher
asked the children to say the vowel sounds as he/she
pointed to the grapheme.[¬e]"', 'Page 185:
[¬s]"Critical to decoding unknown multisyllabic words is
the ability to decode the segmented word parts iden\xad
tified within the word. In this format, reading word
parts, the instructor asked students to sound out a
word part (e.g., ub, sist, lent, bois, feet) silently
and to say the word part on signal for unison
responses."
"Following unison drill on the word parts,
individuals were asked to decode word parts."
"The next format titled correcting close approxima\xad
tions using context involved altering the pronunciation
of multisyllabic words to match aural/oral language or
a sentence context. Training in this preskill involved
oral exercises in which the teacher pronounced a word
with a minor error[¬e]"', 'Page 186:
[¬s]"After pronouncing the isolated
word, the teacher presented the word in a sentence
(e.g., The army is under his _______ .) with the same
pronunciation error and asked students to correctly
pronounce the word to match the sentence context. If
an error occurred, the teacher repeated the it"
"In the final two formats, students were taught to
say isolated affixes (prefixes and suffixes) and to
locate these parts within multisyllabic words. The
first set of affixes introduced were prefixes. The
teacher presented a stimulus sheet containing common
prefixes."
"In the introductory portion of this format,
word parts at the beginning and end of words, the
teacher pronounced an example word containing the pre\xad
fix (prevent) and the prefix in isolation (pre). The
students were then asked to pronounce the prefix.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 164:
[¬s]"The purpose of this study was to investigate the

fifth graders with instruction related to the decoding

int_training_ht:
['Page 206:
[¬s]"Four research assistants and the experimenter served as teachers in this study. All of the research assistants were completing a Master's Degree in Special Education, were involved in a training program for teachers of the mildly handicapped at the University of Oregon, and had taught at least two years."
"In addition,
all of the teachers had received extensive training in
direct instruction procedures and had experience
teaching one of the commercial Direct Instruction
programs (e.g., Corrective Reading, DISTAR, or
Morphographic Spelling.)"
"Initially, the instructors were trained in the
administration of pre and post test measures.[¬e]"', 'Page 207:
[¬s]"experimenter explained the procedures and after the
assistants had examined the teacher wording and
recording procedures, the experimenter modeled the
testing procedures with a child."
"The assistants then
practiced administering the tests to each other and
finally administered the tests to the experimenter
with an emphasis on correct recording and verbal
directions. Given the simplicity of the testing
procedures, these training activities proved
sufficient."
"Basically the same training procedures were used
for introducing the scripted formats to be used in the
study.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 214:
[¬s]"During the course of this study, an observer were
intermittently checked to see if the instructors were
following the prescribed instructional procedures and
daily scripts.[¬e]"', 'Page 215:
[¬s]"Each of the
instructors were observed six times during the study.
Because of the variance in the procedures from day to
day and format to format, a simple checklist of obser\xad
vable behaviors could not be used."
"Instead, the scripts
were segmented into parts (e.g., introduction, uni\xad
son drill, individual turns, corrections) and a +
(correctly used procedure) or a - (incorrectly used
procedure) was recorded for each of the prescribed
procedures.[¬e]"', 'Page 215:
[¬s]"Ninety-eight percent adherence to the
prescribed scripts was obtained across the 36-classroom
observations with a range from 96% to 100% correctly
executed teaching behaviors.[¬e]"']

"m. Children were in-
structed to represent phonemes in one-, two-, or
three-phoneme items by moving disks from the
top half of a standard letter-sized card to the
bottom hal"
". They were taught to say the i[¬e]"', 'Page 9:

ously move a disk to represent each phoneme.
After moving the disks, the children were asked

phoneme item"
"After the third week of say-it-and-move-it

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"theme involving a search for Daisy, the friendly dragon who
lives in a fairy tale world. As children master individual levels within the program,
they gain clues to the location in which Daisy is hiding, and by completing all the
instructional activities, they can eventually discover her hiding place"
"Daisy Quest
and Daisy’s Castle are interactive programs that present material via both syn-
thetic and digitized speech"
"The program also uses colorful graphics and accepts
input from a child via a “mouse.” The programs keep track of children’s progress
through the imaginary world in which Daisy is hiding, as well as allowing the[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"child a wide range of choice about the actual sequence of instructional activities
that are followed"
"Daisy Quest teaches the following skills: 1) recognizing words that rhyme;
2-4) recognizing words that have the same beginning, middle, and ending sounds
(with each skill addressed in a separate instructional activity); while Daisy’s
Castle teaches these additional skills: 1) recognizing words that can be formed
from a series of phonemes presented as onset and rhyme; 2) recognizing words
that can be formed from a series of separately presented phonemes; 3) counting
the number of sounds in words."
"After completing the tutorial, the child was able to
demonstrate mastery of the skill or concept by “moving” to another area in the
program and answering specific questions"
"The mastery exercises contained both
yesho and multiple choice practice items[¬e]"']

[¬s]"phonetically-oriented reading instruction"
"generalized word reading skills[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"The Hint and Hunt I program, developed by Beck and Roth, was designed to
acquaint children with the basic short vowel sounds and provide practice in
identifying words containing those sounds [13]. The first activity, Hint, exposed
children to the medial vowel sounds contained in simple, one-syllable words, and
then provided practice by requiring students to make a series of simple responses
(i.e., distinguishing between “bat” and “bet”). The second activity, Hunt,
employed a game format to provide extensive speed-oriented practice in recogniz-
ing words and nonsense syllables that contain the vowel sounds introduced in the
instructional phase of the program. Each student recorded his/her score upon
completion of the Hunt phase of each game. A student was promoted to the next
level, when he/she had scored 1,000 points or higher on four consecutive games.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 89:
[¬s]"The district reading specialist, kindergarten teachers, and Title I aids
administered a screening instrument during kindergarten registration in April 2003
(Appendix E). The screening instrument was used to place children into program
and non-program status.
The independent variable (phonological awareness instruction) was
administered daily for 2 hours June 9 - July 4, 2003, to 93 children that scored
below 54 points on the screening instrument. Children received explicit
phonological awareness instruction from trained early childhood educators. The
program was designed to build on existing family literacy practices and to increase
phonological awareness skills including: word comparison, rhyming, syllable
segmentation, sentence segmentation, initial sounds, onsets/rimes segmentation and
blending, and phoneme manipulation, segmentation and blending. Parents were
invited to the program one day per week to receive training specific to home[¬e]"', 'Page 90:
[¬s]"interventions in phonological awareness (Appendix C). The parents were asked to
implement phonological awareness activities into the daily homework of their
child.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The purpose of this study was to determine if prekindergarten children who
participated in an explicit phonological-awareness training program, which
included their parents as teachers, entered kindergarten at a reading readiness level
higher than would have been expected had they not participated in the program.
An additional goal of this research was to demonstrate the utility of the regression
discontinuity design in program evaluation.[¬e]"']

"The LCSD Kindergarten
Readiness Screening was used to assign children to program or nonprogram status.
A cut score was established and the children who scored below the cut point on the
LCSD Kindergarten Readiness Screening (93 children) received treatment in the
program. Those children, who scored above the cut point on the LCSD
Kindergarten Readiness Screening (244 children) were placed in the comparison
group. This method of assignment, adherence to a cut score, was consistent with
the regression discontinuity (RD) design used in the study.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"The treatments were (a) word recognition training only,
(b) reading comprehension training only, (c) combined
word recognition and reading comprehension training, and
(d) treated control that only practiced reading-related skills.[¬e]"']
int_name_info: Word Recognition Training Only (For purposes of this coding)
int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Word recognition training. During the first 4 minutes of
training, correspondences between letters and phonemes
were taught explicitly. These correspondences were the
most frequent ones in words in primary-grade reading
material (Fry, Polk, & Fountoukidis, 1984) that are mostly[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"of Anglo-Saxon origin (Balmuth, 1992). In any one session,
12 to 24 correspondences were introduced or reviewed,
and altogether, 107 correspondences were practiced four
or five times during the course of the tutorial. For exact
instructional procedures and rationale, see Berninger et al.
(2000)."
"Specific correspondences were introduced on the
basis of difficulty level established in four prior interven\xad
tion studies with first and second graders (Berninger,
1998): first, one-letter consonant spelling units and short
vowels; second, two-letter consonant blends and long
vowels with silent e; third, two-lettcr vowel teams; and
finally, two-letter r- and I- controlled vowels and conso\xad
nant digraphs or consonant combinations with silent
letters."
"In the first 12 lessons, children practiced reading 20
different structure words and 20 different content words in
each lesson, with 120 structure words and 120 content
words practiced altogether. Teachers kept a running record
of which words either of the children in an instructional
pair missed. From this information, a list was constructed
of 18 structure words (although, neither, though, could,
except, through, since, unless, during, behind, beneath,
against, toward, upon, either, where, while, underneath) and
18 content words (pupil, talk, circus, grade, salt, pencil,
example, cattle, uncle, smile, heat, shoe, country, pony,"
"brain, bread, mouth, knife) that most children missed
during the one time they were presented in the first 12
lessons. Only these words were taught in the last 12
lessons and used in the data analyses of changes from
initial exposure during the first 12 lessons to posttest score
after 12 training sessions. Six structure and six content
words were practiced in each lesson (with each of the 18
words repeated four times during the remaining 12 lessons)."
"In the last 12 lessons, during the explicit word recogni\xad
tion component of the word recognition only and combined
treatments, the teacher listened to each child in the pair
pronounce each of the words presented one at a time, while
the other child did an independent coloring activity. The
children alternated as to who read to the tutor first and
who did the independent activity first. The tutor offered
feedback for any mispronounced word. Once feedback was
provided, children learned to read the words fairly rapidly."
"This activity did not take very long because additional
feedback often did not have to be given. Feedback con\xad
sisted of the teacher (a) directing the child’s attention to
each spelling unit in left to right order, pronouncing the
associated phoneme, and synthesizing the phonemes to
pronounce the word; and (b) noting when letters in a
spelling unit had to be photographed (memorized) by the
“photographic leprechaun in the mind’s eye.” Tutors used a
prepared representation of each word that noted
phonemically recodable spelling units and left a blank
space in the word for spelling units that could not be
recoded phonemically"
"During the last 10 minutes of word recognition training,
children played word games (Bear, Invernizzi, Templeton,
& Johnston, 2000) that were designed to encourage
reflection about the different phonemes associated with the
same target spelling unit. In each lesson, they played two
kinds of games: (a) sorting words according to alternative
phonemes for the same spelling unit and (b) generating
their own words to illustrate alternative phonemes associ\xad
ated with the same spelling unit.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"A five-prong approach was used to achieve and monitor
the fidelity of treatment implementation. First, a compre\xad
hensive intervention manual was written with all details for
implementing each of the 24 lessons for the four condi\xad
tions; tutors were required to review this manual periodi\xad
cally. Second, training sessions were held for all tutors and
the research coordinator before the instructional experiment
began. Third, the tutors and the research coordinator were
required to attend weekly meetings at which the first author
reviewed all instructional procedures and everyone[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"discussed any problems that arose so that problems could
be resolved in the same way by everyone. Fourth, before
each session, tutors were required to review a checklist that
outlined general procedures to be followed. Throughout the
project, tutors also were required to complete this checklist
after each session to self-monitor their delivery of each
intervention and to submit completed checklists to the
research coordinator. These procedures included time limits
for each component of a treatment. Fifth, at the beginning
of the project, tutors brought audiotapes of their delivery of
each treatment to the research coordinator for review.
Midway through the project, tutors were asked to audiotape
two consecutive sessions of each condition and submit these
eight tapes for review."
"The research coordinator evaluated
each of these lessons on the basis of the same performance
criteria as on the checklist, which included adherence to time
components of the intervention.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"At this midway evaluation,
the tutors achieved, on average, 93.2% compliance with
procedures for word recognition training, 96.1% compliance
with procedures for reading comprehension training, 95.4%
compliance with procedures for combined word recognition
and reading comprehension training, and 93.5% compliance
with procedures for the practice control. Average fidelity
ratings across treatments ranged from 94.1 % to 98% to 90%
to 95.7% for individual tutors.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"3) The third activity in this 5-step plan gave children the opportunity to
develop more automatic recognition of words that they had practiced previ-
ously on the sound board. Once they could construct and accurately read
on the sound board a pool of phonetically regular words, these words were
put on ﬂash cards and the children practiced reading them quickly."
"4) Next, children engaged in 10 to 15 minutes of reading connected
text. Children read phonetically controlled readers from the Primary Phonics
series[¬e]"', 'Page 11:
[¬s]"5) The last step ofeach lesson included a short writing to dictation activity.
Generally, 4 to 6 words and a sentence were dictated. Teachers dictated words
drawn from word lists that were practiced on the sound boards or words
encountered in the phonetically controlled readers. Children were directed
to print vowel headings at the top ofeach dictation pag[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"Treatment children began the ?rst grade year with a review ofthe phoneme
awareness and letter sound activities presented in kindergarten."
"In addition to practicing phoneme segmentation activities and games
used during kindergarten, part of the ﬁrst grade review and transition phase
included introducing all letter sounds (not just the 8 sounds introduced during
the kindergarten program), using selected workbook pages for the ﬁrst time
for additional practice connecting letters to sounds, and learning some high
frequency words that would appear in the early readers[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"Although groups began the ﬁrst grade 5-step reading program at different
times in ﬁrst grade (depending on the number ofweeks spent in phonological
awareness and sound-symbol review activities), once a group began the 5-step
program, the group followed the steps described below."
"1) Each lesson began with a brief and quick-paced (1 to 2 minutes) review
ofsound-symbol associations learned in previous lessons and the introduction
of new sound-symbol correspondences"
"2) The second step in the program was instruction in phoneme analysis and
blending skills. To avoid the pitfalls of the letter-by-letter blending strategy
that teachers often use, a blending technique adapted from Engelmann
(1969) was utilized.[¬e]"']

int_objec_info: To develop phonological awareness and accurate and ﬂuent decoding skills and facilitate reading achievement in underachieving 1st-grade students.
int_training_ht:
['Page 12:
[¬s]"Teacher training. Prior to and during the ?rst grade intervention (from August
to June), treatment teachers and their teaching assistants participated in 13,
2-hour inservice workshops (two in August and September and then one
every month through June)."
"During these sessions, teachers learned how
young children acquire literacy skills and about the role of phonological
processes in learning to read. Teachers learned how to provide explicit
instruction in the alphabetic code using the 5-step plan, developed sample
lessons, and discussed matters such as pacing."
"In addition to the inservice program, the project coordinator
and a doctoral student in education visited the treatment schools weekly
to answer questions, monitor treatment ﬁdelity, assess the progress of the
various groups, and monitor the progress of individual children.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"Each 15 to 20 minute lesson consisted of
three parts: (a) say-it-and-move-it phoneme segmentation activities, (b)
segmentation-related activities; and (c) letter name and letter sound training.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"The say-it-and-move-it activities were designed
to teach children to segment words into phonemes."
"Children were taught to
move disks from the top half of an 8 ½ by 11 inch card to the bottom half to
represent the phonemes in one-, two-, and three-phoneme items. First,
children learned to represent single sounds (e.g., 'i'), then double sounds (e.g.,
'i-i'), then two phoneme items (e.g., 'it'), and finally three phoneme items (e.g.,
'lip', 'sun')."
"The segmentation-related activities included activities involving various
degrees of segmentation. For example, a sound categorization task"
"children
were asked to group words on the basis of rhyme or alliteration"
"children were given booklets containing
pictures of objects representing simple consonant-vowel-consonant words
(e.g., fan, sit, lip). Underneath each picture was a series of boxes representing
the number of phonemes in the word. Children learned to say the word
slowly and simultaneously move a disk to the appropriate box to represent
each phoneme in the word."
"A third part of each lesson involved direct instruction in letter names and
letter sounds."
"Eight letters were included in our interven-
tion (a, m, t, i, s, I; f,, b). These letters were selected because combinations of
these letters generate a significant number of real words, using the consonant-
vowel-consonant pattern. Illustrated alphabet cards were used to reinforce
initial sounds. For example, the r card had a picture of a red rooster in red
running shoes and the t card showed two teenagers talking on telephones.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"The goal of this study was to train kinderdergarten teachers and their
teaching assistants to provide phoneme awareness activities to small groups
of children in the regular classroom (during the regular school day) and to
compare the phoneme awareness, letter-sound knowledge, and the reading
and spelling skills of these children to the skills of children who did not have
this instruction.[¬e]"']

theoretical framework to support the teaching of phonological awareness,
and they were given opportunities to practice activities and to ask questions
about the implementation of the program.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"Prior to working with the treatment children, tutors completed a 45-hr,
15-session training program in August and September, directed by a
colleague with extensive early intervention and teacher training experience.
The training program included a review of the project; current research in
early reading acquisition, with an emphasis on phonological processing and
alphabetic coding; the structure of the English language; and specific
practice using the systematic and explicit teaching strategies to be followed
in this study. Tutors also met with Benita A. Blachman and Sheila M.
Clonan for eight additional 2-hr training sessions—approximately one each
month beginning in October[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 122:
[¬s]"(Project 2719). Director: ELIZABETH ANN BORDEAUX,"
"Group A, considered the[¬e]"', 'Page 123:
[¬s]"control group, used only materials being used at the time the study
began. Group B, in addition to the basal text program, used an inten\xad
sive phonetic approach. Group C used both the basal program and the
intensive phonetic approach in addition to a sensory experience ap\xad
proach.[¬e]"', 'Page 125:
[¬s]"(Project 2697). Director: ROBERT B. HAYES,"
"The
four programs and the materials used were: I] an eclectic, “whole
word” reading program as represented by the Scott-Foresman Company
(Robinson, et al., 1960); 2] a “phonic” reading program as repre\xad
sented by the J. B. Lippincott Company (McCracken & Walcutt, 1963);
3] a combination eclectic, “whole word-phonic” reading program as
represented by the Scott-Foresman materials (Robinson, et al., 1960),
supplemented with the Phonics and Word Power (Johnson, et al.,
1964); 4] a language arts approach using the Initial Teaching Alpha\xad
bet as a medium, represented by the i/t/a Publications Inc.[¬e]"', 'Page 127:
[¬s]"(Project 2650). Director:
JOHN C. MANNING"
"In the first treatment group, the teacher’s manual accompany\xad
ing the Ginn Basic Reading Series (Ousley & Russell, 1964) was used
to develop the instructional materials. With the second group, basic
visual and auditory discrimination skills in letter knowledge, word
recognition, word meaning, and word analysis were stressed and sub\xad
sequent reading instruction was programed in a levels design using the
Ginn Series for vocabulary and story content only. In addition to the
basic reading program used with the second group, written language
procedures were used with the third group[¬e]"', 'Page 129:
[¬s]"(Project
2675). Director: HELEN A. MURPHY"
"Three different reading programs were included in the study;
each was used in ten first-grade classrooms. One group followed the
“gradual phonics approach” found in the Scott-Foresman (Robinson,
et al., 1960—62) readers and workbooks. A second group followed the
systematic Speech-to-Print Phonics with a visual word study. The third
group also used the Speech-to-Print Phonics with an emphasis on writ\xad
ing responses.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"Sing, Spell, Read and Write (SSRW), was
designed to provide an "integrated" approach for teaching spoken
language, reading, spelling, and writing, either as a stand-alone
reading /language arts program or as a supplement and booster to basal
reading instruction.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"The SSRW program consists of several charts, books (both readers and
workbooks), letter and word cards, tests, and audio tapes. The audio
tapes contain songs about several phonics generalizations. Through the
tapes, the students learn the sounds of letters and letter combinations.
The program has a "racetrack" chart which is posted in each classroom.
During the program, each student's progress is noted by placement of a
race car on the chart."
"Throughout the program, students learn the letters, generalizations,
and spelling of words to the accompaniment of songs recorded on audio
tapes. The songs all correspond to charts which are placed either on the
walls or as in some cases, students have a copy of the chart at their
desks. While the song is being sung, students are to follow along,
usually with one student pointing the direction on the accompanying
chart.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Reading Intervention for Poor Readers at the Transition to Secondary School[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"With suitable adaptation to ensure age appropriateness, the RI program developed by Hatcher et al. (2006) is employed to target decoding skills, and a new RI and Comprehension (C) program (RI + C), which combines RI with the oral language program from Clarke et al. (2010), is used to target language comprehension as well as decoding difficulties."
"We conducted an RCT in which both interventions were delivered by the same TAs in each school. To examine whether gains made by the intervention groups were greater than those made through standard classroom instruction, we included a waiting list control group.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"The RI sessions contained six components: (a) reading an easy-level book; (b) reading an instructional-level book, during which a running record was taken; (c) letter knowledge, word level, and phonological work; (d) writing; (e) introduction to a new instructional-level book; and (f) reading aloud from a new instructional-level book.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"The present study has two aims. The first aim is to investigate whether reading intervention delivered to secondary school pupils on a 1:1 basis by trained TAs would be effective. The second is to investigate whether pupils with poor word reading skills would benefit more from intensive intervention in decoding skills or a combined program of decoding and language comprehension support.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"The interventions were delivered by TAs who received 5 days of intensive training and ongoing e-mail, telephone, and in-school support where necessary. Each intervention program shared the same basic structure and consisted of three 35-min sessions per week for 20 weeks (35 hr intervention per child).[¬e]"']

ness (Küspert and Schneider, 2003). It contained listening exercises,
rhyming exercises, phoneme recognition exercises, syllable exer-
cises, and the introduction of the concepts “word” and “sentence.”"
"Typical early sessions contained listening tasks that involved eve-
ryday sounds and rhyming with animal names. Children closed
their eyes and guessed the sounds that the trainer produced or
chose words that rhymed with an animal name such as cat. Other
commonly used tasks were clapping the syllables of the animal,
plant, or object displayed on a picture card as well as guessing the
last phoneme of a word given by the trainer. Typical sessions at the
end of the trainings phase included more difficult tasks such as the
identification of words in sentences.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"One
experimental program instructed par\xad
ticipants in sound-symbol correspon\xad
dence and PA (LPA) and the other
program integrated PA, instruction in
sound-symbol correspondence, and
speech perception (SP/LPA).[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"The two
experimental programs consisted of
intensive, systematic instruction in let\xad
ter sounds and PA. They differed only
in speech perception training, which
was introduced only in the second
treatment condition (SP/LPA)."
"In each training
session, the children were trained in
one specific phoneme. The phonemes
were presented in the following order:
/m/, /f/, /r/, /b/, /n/, /p/, /1/,/s/,
/d/, /t/, /k/, /g/, /x/, /r/, /©/. The
last five sessions were designed to re\xad
view the more difficult phonemes. In
each training session, words with dif\xad
ferent syllabic structures were pre\xad
sented (CV, CVC, CCV)."
"The LPA program emphasized the
acquisition of individual letter-sound
correspondences and of PA skills.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"The aim of the SP/ LPA program was
to train speech discrimination, individ\xad
ual letter-sound correspondences, and
PA skills."
"In each session, after these speech
discrimination tasks, the children in
the SP/LPA group were given the
same training and tasks as the children
in the LPA group: letter-sound corre\xad
spondence, phoneme identification,
segmentation, phoneme deletion, pho\xad
neme blending. The only difference
with the LPA group was in the seg\xad
mentation, phoneme deletion, and
blending tasks because we reduced to
four the number of words presented,
with the aim that both programs
would take the same amount of time.
The same sequence of instructional ac\xad
tivities was administered to both ex"
"perimental groups: explanation, dem\xad
onstration, questions, and feedback.
The children were given enough help
to be able to resolve the activity suc\xad
cessfully, and this help was gradually
reduced."
"The SP/LPA group received speech
discrimination, letter-sound corre\xad
spondence, and PA training. The LPA
group received training only in letter\xad
sound correspondence and PA. The
control group did not receive any re\xad
medial reading assistance beyond their
general education instruction.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The purpose of this study was to ex\xad amine the influence of SP as one of the components of phonological training on the phonological and reading abili\xad ties of children with RD."
"We addressed this question by comparing the effec\xad tiveness of two experimental training programs with the reading program usually provided by schools. One experimental program instructed par\xad ticipants in sound-symbol correspon\xad dence and PA (LPA) and the other program integrated PA, instruction in sound-symbol correspondence, and speech perception (SP/LPA). We ex\xad pected that if SP is a precursor of PA, the SP/LPA program would have more impact on PA than the LPA program. In contrast, if SP contributes directly to reading, the SP/LPA program would be better than the LPA program at im\xad proving reading."
"This result supports the hypothesis of
McBride-Chang (1996) that speech per\xad
ception may influence word reading
indirectly, through its association with
phonological awareness. McBride-
Chang et al. concluded that speech
perception can be a precursor of PA.
Thus, training that involves both
speech perception and PA should be
particularly effective in improving
reading skills. However, in the litera\xad
ture reviewed, we found no studies
that trained in speech perception, pho\xad
nemic awareness, and instruction in
sound-symbol correspondence as a
means to improving reading.[¬e]"']

int_name_info: Sixteen products selected for the study grouped into four areas  first grade reading, fourth grade reading, sixth grade math, and algebra.  For the purpose of this coding the focus is first grade reading.
int_desc_ht:
['Page 17:
[¬s]"Sixteen products were selected by ED based on public submissions and ratings by the study team and expert review panels. Products were grouped into four areas: first grade reading, fourth grade reading, sixth grade math, and algebra."
"Educational technology is used for word processing, presentation, spreadsheets,
databases, internet search, distance education, virtual schools, interactions with simulations
and models, and collaboration over local and global networks. Technology also is used as
assistive devices for students with disabilities and to teach concepts or skills that are difficult
or impossible to convey without technology.[¬e]"', 'Page 22:
[¬s]"The first grade study was based on five reading software products that were
implemented in 11 districts and 43 schools. The sample included 158 teachers and
2,619 students. The five products were Destination Reading (published by Riverdeep), the
Waterford Early Reading Program (published by Pearson Digital Learning), Headsprout
(published by Headsprout), Plato Focus (published by Plato), and the Academy of Reading
(published by Autoskill).[¬e]"', 'Page 38:
[¬s]"One of the arguments made for using technology in
classrooms is that it shifts student and teacher roles in ways that lead to more learning. For
example, when students are working with software, every student can construct a response
to a question, rather than just the student called on by the teacher.[¬e]"']

['Page 17:

int_training_ht:
['Page 21:
[¬s]"Nearly All Teachers Received Training and Believed the Training Prepared
Them to Use the Products. Vendors trained teachers in summer and early fall of
2004 on using products. Nearly all teachers attended trainings (94 percent to 98
percent, depending on the grade level). At the end of trainings, most teachers
reported that they were confident that they were prepared to use the products with
their classes. Generally, teachers reported a lower degree of confidence in what they
had learned after they began using products in the classroom.[¬e]"', 'Page 48:
[¬s]"On average, vendors provided about one day of training (7.5 hours), varying from 2 to
18 hours across products. Vendors also provided support during the school year. Modes for
ongoing support included e-mail or telephone help desks (69 percent of teachers reported
receiving this kind of help), product representatives visiting teachers (55 percent), and
additional training at schools (39 percent). The need for such additional support is suggested
by the finding that by the time of the first classroom observation (generally about mid-fall),
when most teachers had begun to use products, the proportion of teachers indicating that
the initial training had adequately prepared them had declined from 95 percent at the end of
the initial training to 60 percent.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 31:
[¬s]"The study tests whether selected reading and mathematics products are effective when districts volunteer to participate and schools and teachers volunteer to implement products. The voluntary aspect of the study and the fact that districts and schools were participating in a study may introduce a difference between measured effectiveness reported by the study, effectiveness in actual use, and effectiveness reported by other studies. For example, effectiveness as measured by this study might be higher than effectiveness in actual use because schools and teachers volunteered for the study, and the study also purchased software and hardware for classrooms and schools when upgrades were needed for products to operate. In actual use, products might be placed in classrooms of teachers who do not want to use them and may not use them effectively, which presumably would imply lower levels of effectiveness."
"Effectiveness as measured by the study might be lower than what has been reported by
other studies because this study used an experimental design. Because teachers were
randomly assigned as part of the experiment, factors that may have predisposed teachers to
use products more effectively and that confound actual effectiveness with teacher
characteristics are controlled by the experimental design.[¬e]"']
int_cost_ht: ['Page 22:\n[¬s]"The study estimated the average licensing fees for the products to\nbe about $100 a student for the school year, with a range of $53 to $124.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"Whether
random assignment achieved its objective can be assessed by examining baseline
characteristics of teachers in the two groups. Table II.5 shows teacher characteristics and
p-values of tests of equivalence. After accounting for multiple comparisons, none of the
teacher differences is statistically significant. However, all the characteristics are entered into
models to adjust for remaining differences."
"The study did not randomly assign students to teachers, but Table II.5 shows that
students in treatment and control classrooms were similar on fall test scores, age, and
gender. After accounting for multiple comparisons, none of the differences is significant.12
Standard scores for the TOWRE test, which averaged about 109, place students in about the
67th
percentile nationally, higher than their performance on the SESAT, where the average
students were at about the 50th
percentile. (The simple correlation between scores was about
0.70.) These differences may arise because of differences in what is being tested, differences
in how the test is conducted (the TOWRE is one on one and the SESAT is administered in
groups), or differences in the norm samples on which the percentiles are based.13[¬e]"']

clust_anal_ht:
['Page 17:
[¬s]"Within each school, teachers were randomly assigned to be able to use the study
product (the treatment group) or not (the control group). Control group teachers were able to use other
technology products that may have been in their classrooms. The study administered tests to students in
both types of classrooms near the beginning and end of the school year. The study also observed treatment
and control classrooms three times during the school year and collected data from teacher questionnaires
and interviews, student records, and product records. Because students were clustered in classrooms, and
classrooms were clustered in schools, effects were estimated using hierarchical linear models.[¬e]"', 'Page 57:
[¬s]"Classroom and School Moderators
Classroom and school characteristics may help explain the variability of effects
observed in Figure II.2."
"he moderating effect of these characteristics was investigated by
interacting the treatment indicator with classroom characteristics at the second level and
adding an equation to the model’s third level that specified the treatment effect as a function
of school characteristics.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"The Reading Rescue model was implemented with the following features
in the present study. The instructors were personnel already employed by
schools, including paraprofessionals, reading specialists, and credentialed
teachers. They received on-site training, supervision, and coaching. The
students were low-SES, language-minority first graders reading near the bottom
of their class as indicated by low scores on literacy tests. The instruction
involved one-to-one tutoring. It was comprehensive in covering all five com\xad
ponents identified as evidence-based and essential by the National Reading
Panel (2000) (i.e., phonemic awareness, systematic phonics, fluency, vocabu\xad
lary, and reading comprehension). Tutors kept records of students’ perfor\xad
mance, and they tested students to assess readiness for higher level lessons and
texts. The costs to schools were relatively modest because existing school staff
members rather than outside, specially trained teachers were used as tutors.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The main purpose of the present study was to obtain
evidence regarding the effectiveness of a comprehensive tutoring interven\xad
tion model, Reading Rescue (RES), when it is applied to teach language\xad
minority struggling readers in first grade.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Linnea C. Ehri
Lois G. Dreyer
Bert Flugman
Alan Gross
Graduate Center, City University of New York[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"The tutors were taught how to pro\xad
vide the intervention by RES program staff. Training was guided by the
Reading Rescue Tutor Handbook (N. Hoover, 2001). The initial phase con\xad
sisted of 5 days of workshops delivered at the schools. The first 2 days at the
beginning of the school year developed tutors’ understanding of the reading
process; the components of the intervention model; the purpose, adminis\xad
tration, and scoring of the classwide screening assessments; and how to
begin working with students. The next 3 days of training took place after
tutoring had begun and focused on the lessons."
"A school coordinator who was a member of the school’s staff served as an
on-site resource whose role was to provide modeling, feedback, and support to
tutors; to help tutors form a peer coaching team; and to monitor implementa\xad
tion of the program. The coordinator had other literacy-related responsibilities
within the school but did not have classroom teaching duties. Coordinators were
in their 2nd or 3rd year of implementation. They had attended advanced train\xad
ing institutes. They were given all the materials necessary, including videotaped
lessons, to continue the training of tutors in their school. They were expected to
schedule regular staff development meetings. RES program staff returned to each
school several times to provide continued training and technical assistance for
tutors and coordinators and for quality assurance visits.[¬e]"']
int_part_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The main purpose of the present study was to obtain
evidence regarding the effectiveness of a comprehensive tutoring interven\xad
tion model, Reading Rescue (RES), when it is applied to teach language\xad
minority struggling readers in first grade[¬e]"']
int_approach_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]"Tutors were randomly assigned to tutees within each school and remained
with those students throughout the intervention. All but three tutors worked
with only one RES student.[¬e]"']
int_who_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"Tutoring was provided by 59 adults who were members of the school staff
and had received formal RES training. The tutors included certified reading spe\xad
cialists with graduate degrees (n = 17), adults certified in other areas (guidance
counseling, math, and social work; n = 15), and paraprofessionals (n = 27).[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"The RES program specifies multiple criteria for
determining when students have met the goals of the program. Data on grad\xad
uation criteria and decisions were not collected in the present study. Rather,
the reading achievement of all the students who received tutoring was
assessed at the end of first grade.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"The intervention began in December[¬e]"']
int_dur_info: Duration varies, as each individual student "graduates" from the programme (intervention) at different times.
int_fidel_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"Tutors completed lesson record sheets as they
tutored during each session. The sheets reminded tutors of assessments,
lesson components, activities, and reading strategies to be taught and mas\xad
tered in each phase. Tutors listed dates, materials used to teach components,
and how students responded[¬e]"', 'Page 12:
[¬s]"To assess characteristics of tutoring and tutors’ adherence to procedures,
two professionals thoroughly familiar with the program scored the records
kept by tutors, whose names had been removed. The scorers analyzed var\xad
ious characteristics, including number of easing-in, easing-out, and regular
tutoring sessions; the number of readings or rereadings of books; and read\xad
ing accuracy levels, which consisted of the proportions of readings that were
completed at a 98% to 100% accuracy level, at a 90% to 97% accuracy level,
and at an accuracy level below 90%. These reading measures were taken
from students’ second exposure to the books when they read them inde\xad
pendently while tutors kept a running record. The first exposure to the books
had occurred during the previous session, when tutors coached students
through the book (see Components 2 and 5 of the intervention, above)."
"To provide an index of tutors’ adherence to the intervention model, judges
rated the following six dimensions of the tutoring records on a 4-point scale
to indicate whether expectations were met: number of books read, difficulty
of the books, selection of elements for word study, features of the sentences
written, instructional decisions made during sentence writing, and provision
of tutoring on a regular basis on the days available. Scores were summed to
provide an adherence measure, with a maximum score of 24. To illustrate, the
criteria used to rate tutors' selection of sentences were as follows:
Rating of 4: Sentences chosen by the tutor for the student to write conformed to
the recommended criteria with regard to their length, complexity, and lexical
features.
Rating of 3: With few exceptions, sentences chosen by the tutor conformed to the
recommended criteria.
Rating of 2: Many sentences chosen by the tutor conformed to the recommended
criteria.
Rating of 1: For the majority of lessons, sentences chosen by the tutor did not
reflect program recommendations, or many sentences were not recorded."
"The two judges rated all of the records independently and were in agree\xad
ment on 90% of their ratings. Disagreements were discussed and resolved.
Nonconformance to the program corresponded to a rating of 1 on five
dimensions and 2 on one dimension (total score of 7). Conformance to the
program corresponded to ratings of 2 or higher on five dimensions and 3 or
higher on one dimension, for a minimum adherence score of 13.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"The "whole language" movement is the most discussed trend in language arts educa- tion today. Most educators resonate with classroom practices proposed by whole language advocates. Some, however, believe that the position taken against the direct teaching of phonics skills by whole language enthusiasts is ill-advised, especially for first-grade children."\n"A modified whole language approach, focusing more directly on word recognition skills, was developed, implemented, and tested in three first-grade classrooms in Provo, Utah. Nine of ten characteristics generally associated with whole language approaches were kept intact in the modified program. However, a daily 15-minute period of total class phonics instruction was added to the program, which is not characteristic of whole language approaches. The year-long study compared the reading achievement effects of the "modified whole language" approach implemented in three classrooms in one school with those obtained from a popular basal approach implemented in three classrooms in a second school in the same school district. Both schools were matched according to[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"word recognition skills, [¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]" One of the difficulties involved in conducting "teaching methods" research is that the social, psychological, and affective variables influencing students\' growth in the classrooms studies are difficult to define, identify, and control. That is a major weakness of this study. Although visits to all of the classrooms involved in the study were made on a regular basis* to ensure treatment fidelity, there were contextual variables within the classrooms affecting students\' reading achievement and attitudes that were not observed, and hence not addressed. Another weakness of this study is that the specific variables impacting attitudes and achievement cannot be directly identified.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 109:
[¬s]"The Direct Phonic scheme covered single[¬e]"', 'Page 110:
[¬s]"letter sounds, c-v-c words and a selection of sight words for .sentences. A
sample lesson is included in Appendix 3. The key elements of the intervention
were that the content was cumulative and very repetitiv"
"The following details are the steps for the supported learning procedure that
were used in each lesson. The staff member models by writing the letter or word
on a whiteboard, they point to it as it is read to the children. The staff used a
prompt ‘listen’ in order to get the pupils’ attention. Then the staff’s leads by
pointing again and then they read in chorus together with the children. The
prompt ‘ready’ signals when the group should start. The adult checks and the
group read together. There is a check on individuals by pointing to a
letter/word/sentence and asking the individual children to read it. If the child
gives an incorrect response, the adult supplies the correct response and then
the child is asked to repeat it."
". The correct responses are praised by nodding,
smiling and saying ‘good’. Each of these daily sessions introduces letters, words
or sentences[¬e]"', 'Page 20:
[¬s]"The
Direct Phonics books address the needs of children who struggle with basic
literacy,[¬e]"', 'Page 80:
[¬s]"Direct Phonics is based on the IAT
programme. It takes the phonics strand and develops it into scripted lesson
plans that make it easy for staff to follow. It is flexible enough to allow for
different rates and patterns of progress. It was designed for children needing a
more systematic and repetitive approach and it has a supported learning
procedure[¬e]"']

['Page 80:

more systematic and repetitive approach and it has a supported learning

base_diff_ht:
['Page 9:
[¬s]"To assess whether the compositions and
characteristics of the ﬁve groups were indeed comparable,
we performed one-way ANOVAs and Chi-squared analyses
on demographic and psycho-educational measures (stan-
dard scores) obtained prior to intervention. An ANOVA
yielded no statistically signiﬁcant ﬁndings for age
[F(4,60) = 0.73, p = .58] or grade [F(4, 60) = .87, p = .49].
Also, the relative composition ofgroups was found tobe sim-
ilar for sex [v2(4, N= 65) = 1.97, p = .74 two-sided] and
race/ethnicity [v2(16, N= 65) = 8.86, p = .92 two-sided].[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Switch-on Reading is an intensive 10-week literacy intervention. It is delivered on a one to one basis by staff, most commonly teaching assistants, who have been trained in the approach. The purpose of Switch-on is to achieve functional literacy for as many pupils as possible, and so to close the reading achievement gap for vulnerable children working below age-expected levels. It is inspired by the well- established intervention Reading Recovery"
" the programme involved regular sessions for pupils who had not achieved Level 4 English at Key Stage 2. The identified pupils in Year 7 attended regular 20-minute reading sessions over the course of the Spring term."
"Each session required students to read from four different books graded on the basis of their difficult[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]" achieve functional literacy for as many pupils as possible, and so to close the reading achievement gap for vulnerable children working below age-expected levels.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]" test the impact of Switch-on as delivered with the developer leading the training and overseeing the provision of the intervention.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"evaluate the impact of the Switch-on intervention on the reading performance of first year secondary students (Year 7) who had not previously achieved Level 4 English at KS2."
"evaluate the impact of Switch-on intervention in relation to key background characteristics of the pupils."
" record the fidelity of the Switch-on intervention through process evaluation, and assess the ease with which it could be scaled-up and implemented with a larger groups of schools.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"The programme began with a two-day training event for staff in order to equip them with the necessary skills to carry out the intervention. The training provided background information on the rationale and content of the Switch-On approach, as well as demonstration of the use of the running record, coding and analysis. Participants then practised the use of the protocol. There was a video demonstration of what a Switch-on reading session looks like. Eighty-three members of the staff from the 19 schools were trained to conduct Switch-on. Of this number 71 went on to deliver the intervention.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Fresh Start (FS) is a catch-up literacy intervention for pupils at risk of falling behind their peers in early secondary schooling. It provides systematic and rigorous practice in phonics so that pupils are at an appropriate level to join the mainstream group after completion of the intervention. Pupils are assessed and then grouped according to their levels of reading ability. Teaching in these groups begins with recognition, practice and blending of sounds and graphemes, based on a set of module booklets.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]"FS aims to support young pupils who somehow missed earlier opportunities and FS is an extra chance to fill those learning gaps. Therefore, FS is tailored to get the pupils off the intervention quickly so that they can participate in mainstream literacy activities.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:\n[¬s]" FS is a complete literacy catch-up package that targets improvements in both reading and writing, but in this randomised control trial the impact has been assessed only for reading comprehension, and after 22 weeks. This was the decision of the school leaders who wanted to assess the impact on reading first.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 14:
[¬s]" There are also two-day staff training workshops offered by Read Write Inc. where experienced FS trainers provide the hands-on training and teacher support visits in the actual classrooms.[¬e]"', 'Page 26:
[¬s]"The classroom management and teacher-pupil communication techniques are prescribed in the training and teacher’s handbook."
"FS training in the schools was given by experienced and professional trainers. In the two-day training, the concept of FS teaching through phonics was discussed along with FS teaching style and the rules of classroom management. The training also provided knowledge about phonemic awareness, how teachers should use modules for practising decoding, and pupils’ assessment and grouping in the classroom.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]" FS training and school support visits have been conducted by the FS trainers (which is standard practice).[¬e]"']

int_cost_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"The direct cost to schools is for the Fresh Start training and material resources required in the intervention. For each pupil the cost of the material is £95.90. The cost of staffing to assist teachers depends largely on each school’s initial position. So, for example, a school with four relevant teachers to be trained and 20 pupils per year group, would have to pay £2,316 or around £116 per pupil.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 66:
[¬s]"Detailed intervention program descriptions may be found in Appendix [¬e]"', 'Page 67:
[¬s]"Treatment A1 and Treatment A2 used Stepping Stones to Literacy consisting of twenty-five, integrated lessons addressing listening, written conventions, phonological awareness, phonemic awareness, and serial processing (Nelson et al., 2004-2005)"
"Treatment B used Road to the Code, included all students Treatment A1, and consisted of forty-four lessons focusing on eight letters (a, m, t, i, s, r, b, & f) and uses only short vowel sounds (e.g., a = /a/ in apple) (Blachman et al., 2000). Each lesson consists of three sections: phoneme identification (a listening activity), letter/sound correspondence, and phonological awareness activity[¬e]"', 'Page 68:
[¬s]"(game-based activities). Program instructions include discussion of pacing, prerequisite student skills, and an overview of phonological and phonemic awareness. The instructions use the generic title teacher for the interventionist but do not define this term with respect to expected training or experience.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 69:
[¬s]"The treatment fidelity checklist (Nelson et al., 2004-2005) was completed by the interventionist. Student attendance was tracked through the checklist and absent participants were provided individual make-up treatment sessions to ensure continued treatment fidelity for all participants.[¬e]"', 'Page 86:
[¬s]"Treatment fidelity was reported by the interventionist using the Stepping Stones to Literacy (Nelson et al., 2004-2005) Treatment Fidelity Self-Evaluation Form. The Road to the Code (Blachman et al., 2000) program did not include a treatment fidelity component and treatment fidelity was evaluated using the same self-reporting form. The form consists of 15 statements related to lesson planning (before, three statements), lesson implementation (during, nine statements), and reflection (after, three statements) with a four-point Likert response scale (never, sometimes, usually, always). Responses were coded as never = 0, sometimes = 1, usually = 2, always = 3. Non-responses were not coded.[¬e]"', 'Page 87:
[¬s]"A copy of the Treatment Fidelity evaluation form is located in Appendix D. Table 12 reports treatment fidelity interventionist\x92s response means and standard deviations for all treatment periods.[¬e]"', 'Page 90:
[¬s]"Generally, treatment fidelity mean scores for all treatment periods indicate that treatment planning and implementation were completed with fidelity.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"For the rime analogy training group,
systematic training in the use of rime spelling units to identify
words was incorporated into the 30-min lesson format of RTRs.
The intervention procedures built on earner work reported in
Iversen and Tunmer (1993) and Greaney and Tunmer (1996). For
each 3- (or 4-) day training cycle, three pairs of target nouns
selected from Elley and Croft's (1989) word frequency count were
presented to each child to read. The words of each pair contained
one of the 37 rime spelling units identified by Wylie and Durrell
(1970)[¬e]"']

['Page 3:
[¬s]"As noted previously, the 36 disabled readers participating in the
intervention study had been selected by the school system for
additional remedial instruction by RTRs.[¬e]"']
base_diff_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The 57 disabled readers were exactly matched on context-free word recognition ability (as measured by the Burl Word Reading Test, New Zealand Revision; Gilmore, Croft & Reid, 1981) on a pairwise basis with children selected from a larger pool of normally developing readers. This also resulted in a very close match on accuracy of recognizing words in connected text, as measured by the Neale Analysis of Reading Ability (Revised) Accuracy subtest (Neale, 1988). The mean reading age of both groups on the Burt Word Reading Test was 6.35 years (SD = 0.56). On the Neale, the mean reading age was 6.13 years (SD = 0.57) for the disabled readers and 6.21 years (SD = 0.54) for the reading-age controls."
"At initial testing, the mean ages of the
children in the rime analogy group, item-specific group, and
normal reader group subsample were 8.23 years, 8.16 years, and
6.72 years, respectively.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Children in the otherclassroom received
traditional instruction (TI) from a basal
reading program with a skills emphasis."
"The reading curriculum included direct
instruction in phonics concepts (e.g., terms
such as "consonant" and "vowel")as well as
in specific letter-sound correspondences.
The children practiced these correspon-
dences in isolation in thebasal readerwork-
book and on supplementary phonics ditto
sheets. Writing opportunities were limited
to responses on commercially prepared
worksheets. Children in the TI classroom
received structured spelling instruction
including weekly spelling tests on word
lists.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"In contrast, traditional basal skills in-
struction employs a part-to-whole method-
ology. Children are provided direct
instruction in individual letter-sound cor-
respondences. A sound, in common to sev-
eral different words, is isolated and
associated with a letter."
"Children practice
listening for the sound as the words are
pronounced. Subsequentpractice, provided
through workbook and ditto exercises, typi-
cally requires children to circle a picture
having the targeted sound. Instructional
focus is primarily upon the acquisition of
letter-sound correspondence information
and less upon the mapping of spoken lan-
guage onto written language. In fact, dur-
ing first grade children are exposed to
approximately 90 different individual
sounds. It is felt that through direct in-
struction on individual letter-sound corre-
spondences children will learn to both
decode and spell words.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"This study examined the intersection of
two concepts, phonemic awareness and
whole language instruction. Specifically,
we were interested in answering the fol-
lowing questions: (a) What is the relation-
ship between instructional approach and
the development ofdecoding skills ofchil-
dren with various levels ofphonemicaware-
ness? (b) Whatis the relationship between
instructional approach and the develop-
ment of spelling skills of children with
various levels ofphonemic awareness? (c)
What is the relationship between instruc-
tional approach and the development of
writing fluency of children with various
levels ofphonemic awareness?[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"For the supplemental instruction, we used Reading Mas-
tery (Engelmann & Bruner, 1988) and Corrective Reading (En-
gelmann, Carnine, & Johnson, 1988). We used these curricula
for the intervention because they focus on the development of
foundational word recognition skills identified as essential to
skilled reading (Rayner et al., 2001) and because they incor-
porate the frequent opportunities for practice and review that
help students learn and remember new skills."
"Students received 30 minutes of supplemental
instruction daily for 2 years[¬e]"']

plemental versus no supplemental instruction on the reading

ing difficulty[¬e]"']

room instruction. All participants, treatment and control, also
received daily reading instruction in their classrooms[¬e]"']

['Page 5:

communities provided the supplemental instruction. The IAs
were an asset to the project because they understood their
community norms and were able to relate well to participants"

teaching experience. Seven of the nine had some previous ex-
perience working with elementary school students in small-
group or tutorial settings[¬e]"']

tion received 6 to 7 months of supplemental reading instruc-

(i.e., 9 months) of instruction in the second year.[¬e]"']

plemental instruction and twice a month thereafter[¬e]"', 'Page 5:

rective feedback. Across observations, lessons were followed

At each assessment, they received $30 for completing a par-
ent questionnaire and a $10 gift certificate if they returned the

viding data about social behavior in a series of three brief

comp_var_rep_ht:
['Page 9:
[¬s]"The analysis included dichotomous terms
for key background influences: gender, selection criteria, ei-
ther poor reading or aggressive behavior, ethnicity, and grade
level. We expected main effects and interactions with time for
these factors, especially selection criteria, ethnicity, and grade
level, but we were unsure about their interactions with treat-
ment effects. For each of these background variables, then, we
tested its main effect and its interactions with time, condition,
and time by condition. The inclusion of these terms also re-
duces the impact of potential confounding effects, such as
with ethnicity and selection criteria.[¬e]"']
clust_anal_ht:
['Page 8:
[¬s]"To model appropriately the repeated assessments nested
within individuals, and individuals nested within treatment
condition, we conducted a random coefficients analysis, also
known as a random-effects regression, linear mixed model, or
multilevel model (Kreft & de Leeuw, 1998; Murray, 1998;"
"The first equation represents the within-person model:
Yij = π0j + π1jTij + rij[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"The next two equations represent the between-person in-
tercept and slope, respectively, and allow us to test the effect
of condition. We coded Cj = 0 for control students and 1 for
intervention students:
π0j = β00 + β01Cj + u0j
π1j = β10 + β11Cj + u1j"
"Substituting the second two equations into the first and
rearranging terms, we obtain the following model, with the
fixed and random terms grouped, which we estimate with SAS
PROC MIXED (Littell et al., 1996; Singer, 1998, 2002; Singer
& Willett, 2003):
Yij = (β00 + β01Cj + β10T1j + β11Cj T1j) + (u0j + u1jTij + rij[¬e]"']
